In this work, the selective hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol has been studied over Pd/TiH2 catalysts. The catalytic performances of several catalysts with different Pd loading (0.2–3% in weight) were discussed, among which a higher selectivity to furfuryl alcohol was obtained over 0.5Pd/TiH2 and it gave rise to a 73% furfural alcohol selectivity at complete conversion at 60 °C. The physicochemical properties of catalysts were well characterized by TEM, XRD, XPS, Raman, TPR and TPD, as well as in-situ DRIFT for the adsorption of the reactant. The size and the electronic state of Pd particles, and the surface defects of catalysts presented significant influence on the catalytic performance. The furfural is preferentially adsorbed with its C=O bond on the boundary of Pd particle and TiH2 support, leading to the high selectivity to furfuryl alcohol. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Selective hydrogenation Pd TiH2 Furfural Furfuryl alcohol Abbreviations FF furfural FOL furfuryl alcohol THFA tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol THFF tetrahydrofurfural Introduction Converting biomass to value-added chemicals is of great significance in modern sustainable chemistry and engineering. Furfural, can be easily obtained from hemicellulose under mild conditions, is one of the most important platform molecules in chemical industry. Furfural (FF) can be converted to furfuryl alcohol (FOL), tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA), methylfuran, methyl-tetrahydrofuran and pentanediols by hydrogenation [1–3]. Among them, around 65% of the global furfural production is converted to FOL [1], which is widely used in the manufacture of resins, adhesives, synthetic fibers, potential fuel/fuel additive, anti-corrosion plastics and membranes [4,5]. In terms of producing FOL from FF, the challenge is to control the C=C or C=O hydrogenation and to prevent from decarbonylation or over hydrogenation. The transition metals such as Cu [6–8], Co [9–11], Ni [12–16], Ru [17–19], Ir [20,21] and Pt [22–24], have been studied and some of them displayed good selectivity to FOL(> 90%). However, for Pd based catalyst it is difficult to selectively obtain FOL in most cases, because the unique electronic structure of Pd always result in an affinity to nonpolar groups (such as C=C bond) other than those polar groups such as C=O bond. Taylor et al. studied the hydrogenation of FF over Pd supported catalysts with different supports [25], almost all the tested catalysts showed higher C=C hydrogenation selectivity than C=O bond. Kwangjin et al. studied a series of supported Pd catalysts and found Pd/Al2O3 could give a selective carbonyl group hydrogenation, and a 55% FOL yield was obtained under the optimized conditions [26]. Yan et al. reported that a ~ 80% FOL selectivity was obtained on Pd/SiO2 at about 40% conversion [27]. Wells et al. tuned the Pd particle size and active site through the optimized colloidal synthesis, and reported a 67% FOL selectivity at 79% FF conversion [28]. Li et al. reported the encapsulation of Pd species within MFI-type zeolites for the hydrogenation of FF, which gave a ~ 90% FOL selectivity at conversion of > 90% at 175 °C [29]. Moreover, the magnetic 5% Pd/MAGSNC composite catalyst showed high selectivity of 74–90% to FOL at the conversion of > 95%. Lamb et al. reported a 66.7% FOL selectivity over PdRe/Al2O3 catalyst in a fix-bed micro-reactor at 150 °C [30]. In order to adjust the catalytic selectivity of catalyst, researchers have paid attention to modify the chemical and electronic states of Pd via doping second metal, surface poisoning, capping by organic groups, and so on [31–38]. For instances, Hutchings et al. adjusted the metal oxidation state by tuning the Ru to Pd ratio and obtained a desired selectivity in the FF hydrogenation to FOL and 2-methyfuran [32]. Medlin et al. used the alkanethiolate self-assembled monolayers to suppress the adsorption of FF on the terrace sites of Pd (supported on Al2O3), and improved the selectivity to FOL and 2-methyfuran [35,36]. Hronec et al. reported that Cu+ site in Pd-Cu catalyst was responsible for the activation of C=O bond and the high selectivity to FOL [37]. Tuning the adsorption configuration of substrate on the surface of catalyst via changing the structure and electronic states of active species has attracted much attention in view of the fundamental research significance, and FF hydrogenation over the supported Pd catalyst is a good model reaction for such a purpose. The strong metal support interaction formed in metal-reducible support system plays a crucial role in hydrogenation and hydrodeoxygenation in view of its contribution to the modulation of catalytic performance. A high reduction temperature is always required to facilitate the defect formation in the support, and the charge transfer, hydrogen spillover, and mass transfer between metal and support. As a hydrogen storage material, TiH2 displays interesting hydrogen storage and activation properties owing to its unique crystalline structure and abundant surface defects. Therefore, the TiH2 supported metal catalyst is expected to exhibit novel metal-support synergy benefited from the charge and hydrogen species transfer within TiH2 or between TiH2 and the supported metal. Besides, the surface defect sites on TiH2 could be beneficial for the adsorption of C=O group of the substrate. In our previous study, Pt/TiH2 displayed interesting heterolytic hydrogenation for the C=O group of cinnamaldehyde [39], where TiH2 support could adsorb C=O bond, generate and transfer the H− species. That motivated us to study the effectiveness of TiH2 support in the hydrogenation reaction of FF to FOL due to its properties different from other conventional supports like TiO2, Al2O3, SiO2; it is difficult to achieve a high selectivity to FOL using Pd catalysts on these supports. Thus, TiH2-supported Pd catalysts was investigated for the hydrogenation of FF, the surface characters of the catalyst have been studied by XRD, H2-TPD, H2-TPR, XPS, TEM, Raman, and in-situ DRIFT, and the factors influencing the catalytic activity, product selectivity, and the adsorption behavior of FF were discussed. The adsorption configuration and catalytic mechanism that account for the high C=O hydrogenation selectivity was also proposed. Experimental Chemicals Commercially available reagents, furfural (Acros; > 97%), Pd(OAc)2 (Shanghai Jiu Ling; > 99.9%), isopropanol, acetone, cyclohexane, methanol, 1,4-dioxane (Beijing chemicals; > 99.5%), methyltetrahydrofuran, tetrahydrofuran, tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol, furfuryl alcohol (Alfa; > 98%), 1-octadecanethiol (Acros; > 96%), and TiH2 (Beijing chemicals; > 99.9%) were used as received. Catalyst preparation The Pd/TiH2 catalysts with various Pd loading were prepared by the wet impregnation method. In a typical preparation, given amount of palladium acetate was dissolved in 5 mL acetone, and then 1.0 g TiH2 support was added with stirring to form a slurry. The slurry was dried at 80 °C in a water bath while stirring until all the acetone was evacuated, and then the mixture was kept at 80 °C in an oven for 12 h. Prior to usage, the catalyst was reduced in H2 flow at 150 °C for 2 h. The catalysts were denoted as XPd/TiH2, where “X” represents the weight percentage of Pd in the catalyst. The surface of TiH2-supported Pd particles was modified by the adsorption of a thiol, 1-octadecanethiol. Such a catalyst was used to examine the contribution of the surface of Pd particles in the target reaction. A given amount of Pd/TiH2 catalyst was reduced at 150 °C for 2 h and cooled to room temperature in N2 stream for 30 min. The sample was then transferred into a glass tube containing 10 mL isopropanol under N2 atmosphere, the thiol was added to the tube (Pd/thiol = 50 in mole), and then the mixture was stirred for 3 h. Finally, the thiol-adsorbed catalyst sample was separated and collected by centrifugation and washing with isopropanol three times and used for the target reaction with no further treatment. The thiol-modified catalysts will be denoted like 0.5 Pd/TiH2(SH) in the following. Catalyst characterization The TiH2 support and Pd/TiH2 catalysts were characterized by the following methods. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray powder diffraction instrument with a Cu–Kα radiation (k = 0.154 nm) in the 2θ range of 20–80° with a scan speed of 1° min−1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried on VG Microtech 3000 Multilab without sputtering. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were taken using a field emission JEOL JEM-2010 instrument at 200 kV. H2 temperature programmed reduction and desorption experiments (H2-TPR/H2-TPD) were conducted on a Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 chemisorption instrument. In a typical H2-TPR experiment, catalyst (50 mg) was pretreated in Ar at 150 °Cfor 1 h to remove physically adsorbed H2O and other impurities. After cooling to room temperature, the sample was flushed for an additional 0.5 h by Ar, and then heated to 900 °Cat a rate of 10 °Cmin−1 in a flowing 5% H2/Ar (50 cm3 min−1). In a typical H2-TPD experiment, catalyst (50 mg) was pre-reduced for 1 h at 150 °C in a flowing 5% H2/Ar. After cooling to room temperature in the atmosphere of H2/Ar and kept for 30 min until the baseline was stable, the sample was flushed for an additional 0.5 h by Ar and then heated to 800 °Cat a heating rate of 10 °Cmin−1 with flowing Ar (50 cm3 min−1). The size and metal dispersion of Pt nanoparticles were examined by CO pulse adsorption at 50 °C with a pulse of CO/He (10%) on Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920. The contents of Pd in the Pd/TiH2 catalysts were measured by Inductively Coupled Plasma (ICP) on ThermoScientific XseriesII. The adsorption of FF was examined by in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in-situ DRIFT) on Thermo Scientific Nicolet 6700 Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy. A catalyst sample was reduced at 150 °Cfor 30 min in the FTIR cell with H2 (30 mL/min) and then cooled down to 20 °C. The cell was purged with He (30 mL/min) for 30 min and the background spectrum was recorded before adsorption. 20 μL FF isopropanol solution (0.2 M) was added to the catalysts dropwisely, and then the time counter was started. The spectrum was recorded at 20 °C every 2 min for 30 min while passing He (30 mL/min). After that, the temperature of the cell was raised to 150 °Cslowly while passing He (30 mL/min). The spectrum was recorded at 150 °C every 2 min until all the physically adsorbed species were removed. Catalytic tests The catalytic performance of TiH2 support and Pd/TiH2 catalysts were tested for the selective hydrogenation of furfural using a 100 mL stainless steel autoclave. Prior to usage the catalyst (100 mg) was reduced in a quartz tube under H2 at 150 °C for 2 h at a heating rate of 2 °Cmin−1. After the reduced catalyst was cooled to room temperature, the carrier gas was changed from H2 to N2. The catalyst was then immediately transferred into the mixture of 2 mmol furfural and 10 mL isopropanol in a 100 mL stainless-steel autoclave under N2 atmosphere to avoid exposure to air. For a typical catalytic reaction, the reactor was flushed with H2 for three times and then sealed, the 2 MPa H2 was purged at the reaction temperature. The reaction was carried out at a given temperature with a stirring rate of 1300 rpm, which was high enough to eliminate the influence of external diffusion. The liquid products after centrifugal separation were analyzed by gas chromatography (Shimadzu, 14 C) equipped with a capillary column (Restek Stabilwax 30 m *0.53 mm *1 μm) and a flame ionization detector (FID). The conversion was determined by 1- (the amount of substrate unreacted) / (the initial amount of substrate loaded) and the product selectivity by (the amount (mole) of a product) / (the amount (mole) of substrate reacted). Results and discussion The reaction route for the selective hydrogenation of FF to FOL was given in Scheme 1 . FOL and tetrahydrofuran-2-carboxaldehyde (THFF) can be produced via hydrogenation of either C=O or C=C of FF, and THFA can be obtained by the complete hydrogenation of all C=C and C=O bonds. Meanwhile, a small portion of isopropyl furfuryl ether might be also formed via dehydration between FF or FOL and isopropanol solvent as previously reported over a Ru/C catalyst in isopropanol, the formed isopropyl furfuryl ether could be converted to FOL through the MPV mechanism [17,19,40]. Several parameters affecting the catalytic performance were screened for the hydrogenation of FF with 0.5Pd/TiH2 catalyst. The influence of reaction temperature on the reactivity and selectivity is shown in Table S1. At temperatures of 40 to 100 °C, the reaction rate increased with temperature, and a moderate temperature of 60 °C was selected for the following experiments. As given in our previous study, the reduction temperature had significant impacts on the chemical and electronic states of catalysts, which ultimately changed the catalytic performance [39]. The influence of reduction temperature is shown in Table S2. The catalyst reduced at 150 °C showed the highest FOL yield of 73% in a reaction time of 3 h. Furthermore, the polarity of solvent was also examined and it significantly affected the catalytic performance (Table S3). In the polar solvent like water, methanol, and isopropanol, the conversion rate was much higher than those in the cyclohexane and 1,4-dioxane. In addition, isopropanol with a medium polarity was more suitable for production of FOL than other solvents. Therefore, the reduction temperature of 150 °C and the solvent of isopropanol was chosen in the following experiments. Catalytic performance over Pd/TiH2 catalysts The results for the hydrogenation of FF over TiH2 itself and Pd/TiH2 catalysts with different loadings are listed in Table 1 . The catalytic performances of TiH2 support and Pd/TiH2 catalysts with different loading of 0.2, 0.5, 1, 1.5, and 3% were compared. The actual Pd loading with weight percentage of these catalysts was determined by ICP as shown in Table S4. It is worthy to mention that the TiH2 itself displayed unexpected activity for the hydrogenation of FF with a 18.9% conversion in 6 h, and the selectivity to FOL reached near 100% in the presence of H2. A 0.2Pd/TiH2 showed a 11.1% conversion and 99% selectivity to FOL in 1 h. With increasing Pd loading to 0.5, 1, 1.5, and 3%, the conversion in 1 h increased to 88.3%, 76.7%, 97.8%, and 80.0%, respectively. With prolonging the reaction time to 6 h, all the conversion of these catalysts reached above 99%, but that of 0.2Pd/TiH2 was only 36.4% and it cannot increase further by extending reaction time, indicating the deactivation of 0.2Pd/TiH2 catalyst. Interestingly, the degree of FOL selectivity decline with extending reaction time was highly related to the Pd loading as seen in Fig. 1 . For all the catalysts examined, the FOL was the dominant product in the initial stage of reaction. The 0.5Pd/TiH2 catalyst displayed a higher selectivity to FOL of 73% at nearly 100% conversion at 3 h, but the selectivity to FOL decreased with reaction time extension, simultaneously selectivity of THFA increased, as the FOL was further hydrogenated to THFA. The same changing trend was also found for the catalysts with different Pd loadings of 1Pd/TiH2, 1.5Pd/TiH2 and 3Pd/TiH2, but the selectivity of FOL decreased largely, indicating that the further hydrogenation of FOL to THFA became much faster over them. At a comparable conversion of 82±6%, the FOL selectivity was 79.6%, 66.2%, 51.8%, and 58.5%; and the site-time-yield based on specific active sites was 702.2, 315.3, 341.4, and 283.8 h−1 over 1Pd/TiH2, 1.5Pd/TiH2 and 3Pd/TiH2, respectively (Table S5). The catalytic performance of 0.5Pd/TiH2 was also compared with the results of Pd-based catalysts reported in the literature as shown in Table S6. A FOL yield of 73% obtained on 0.5Pd/TiH2 was higher than those of the most catalysts of monometallic Pd supported on SiO2, TiO2, Al2O3, MOF, etc. Considering that transfer hydrogenation of furfural in isopropanol may take place in some cases as reported in the literature [41,42], the transfer hydrogenation was examined for the present reaction with CO2 or N2 as reaction gas instead of H2 (Table 1). Under similar reaction conditions, no hydrogenation product was observed in the absence of H2, indicating that the transfer hydrogenation was unlikely to happen, and the hydrogenation product of FF was produced by the molecular H2 in the present catalysis system. Characterization of catalysts The structure and physical properties of the catalysts were examined for exploring the relation between the activity and structure. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of the Pd/TiH2 catalysts displayed typical peaks of the tetragonal phase of TiH1.92 (JSPDF: 25-0982) as seen in Fig. 2 , and the peak at 34.8°, 40.3°, 58.6°, 70.0°, and 73.7° was indexed to the (111), (200), (220), (311), and (222) plane of TiH1.92, respectively [43–45]. The XRD patterns of the Pd/TiH2 samples with different Pd loadings were consistence with those of the TiH2 alone, indicating that the support crystalline structure did not change essentially by loading of Pd and the subsequent reduction. Pd was highly dispersed on the supports in the form of small nanoparticles as no obvious diffraction peaks of Pd were detected. In addition, the high amount of Pd (3%) on the TiH2 could reduce the crystallinity of TiH2 slightly as indicated by the broadening of (111) peak. It is proposed that the redox reaction between the TiH2 support and Pd precursor caused slight changes of TiH2 crystallinity. The H2 reduction behavior of the as-prepared samples was examined by TPR, the results are shown in Fig. 3 . Two main H2 release peaks were observed at 380–520 °C and 520–620 °C for the TiH2 support itself [39,46]. As a hydrogen storage material, hydrogen storage-release competition could exist in TiH2, and H2 release was detected at the operating H2 pressure probably because of the relative higher H2 release rate. It is obviously that the presence of Pd lowered the releasing temperature, that the first H releasing peak moved to 300 °Cfrom 380 °C, this may ascribed to the stored hydrogen of TiH2; the second peak moved to the higher temperatures which may be assigned to the dehydrogenation of β-TiHx to α-Ti phase [47–49]. As shown in H2-TPD (Fig. S1) the hydrogen releasing started from 400 °C and clearly the presence of Pd nanoparticles accelerated the H2 release to some extent as indicated by the shift of the first peak to low temperature. However, Pd showed less influence on the last two releasing peaks, which may be related to the rapid release of hydrogen from the inner phase of the support at high temperature. In addition, a hydrogen storage feature of the TiHx was observed from the H2-TPD-TPR test (Fig. S2, A TPR analysis was carried out subsequently after H2-TPD experiment finished), where a remarkable hydrogen storage peak presented at round 380–520 °C. It should be noted that no obvious hydrogen consumed peak for the reduction of Pd was observed in Fig. 3, which is due to that the Pd could be reduced during the impregnation by the stored hydrogen species in TiH2 which may release and lead the metal precursor to be reduced to zero valence. The Pd particle sizes and morphologies of the Pd/TiH2 catalysts were characterized by TEM in Fig. 4 . Unlike the impregnation on a conventional support, the hydrogen species in TiH2 could reduce Pd2+ to Pd0 during the wet impregnation process involving complicated redox reaction of Pd and nucleation and growth of Pd nanoparticle. For the sample of 0.2Pd/TiH2, the Pd particles dispersed on the surface of TiH2 showed a wide distribution from 2 nm to 14 nm, with an average particle size of 4.5 nm (Fig. 4a). While, for the samples of 0.5Pd/TiH2 and 1Pd/TiH2 catalysts (Fig. 4b and c), they presented fine dispersion of Pd with average particle sizes of ~3.5 and ~5.0 nm, respectively. For the 1.5Pd/TiH2 and 3Pd/TiH2 catalysts, Pd particle presented a slight aggregation and the average particle size increased to ~5.8 and ~8.5 nm, respectively. The metal dispersion of the as-prepared catalysts were also examined by CO pulse adsorption, the 0.5Pd/TiH2 and 1Pd/TiH2 catalysts showed higher dispersion of 42.6% and 34.3% by comparison with 9.9%, 21.4% and 11% of the 0.2Pd/TiH2, 1.5Pd/TiH2 and 3Pd/TiH2 (Table 2 ). The particle sizes determined by TEM was largely different from those estimated from CO pulse adsorption for the 0.2Pd/TiH2, these deviations should be ascribed to the low Pd loading and the wide distribution of Pd particles. The chemical states of the surface Pd, Ti and O species for the catalysts were examined by XPS. Fig. 5 presents the results of Pd 3d XPS signals of the Pd/TiH2 catalysts. The deconvolution of Pd signal indicated that the presence of the Pd2+ and Pd4+ species, as well as the dominant Pd0 species. The peaks at 335.3, 336.3 and 337.9 eV were assigned to Pd03d5/2, Pd2+3d5/2, Pd4+3d5/2 (PdO2), respectively [50,51]. The difference between Pd 3d3/2 and Pd 3d5/2 signals was fixed to 5.2 eV, and the area ratio was 2/3. The Pd0/(Pdδ++ Pd0) ratio on the surface was 79.8%, 81.5%, 67.3%, 72.7%, and 85.0% for 0.2Pd/TiH2, 0.5Pd/TiH2, 1Pd/TiH2, 1.5Pd/TiH2, and 3Pd/TiH2, respectively. Interestingly, the content of Pd4+ species was non-negligible at low Pd loading of 0.2 and 0.5%, and a higher Pd0 content was obtained on the catalyst with a loading of 3% Pd which contained bigger Pd nanoparticles. Fig. 6 shows the Ti 2p chemical states of the catalysts. Ti species of Ti3O5 and Ti4+ were detected with peak centered at 458.5, and 459.0 eV, respectively [43,44,52,53]. Ti3O5 species were dominant on the surface of all the Pd/TiH2 catalysts, and almost no Ti2+ species were detected. The surface of TiH2 supported catalysts was quite complicated with the coexistence of abundant Ti3O5, Ti3+ species and Ti4+ species, which were influenced by the loading of Pd. Evidently, the 0.2Pd/TiH2 and 0.5Pd/TiH2 catalysts displayed higher Ti3O5/Ti4+ ratio, suggesting a higher defect contents on them. Similarly, three types of oxygen species were also involved in the catalysts, as shown in Fig. 7 . The first one was related to the oxygen specie in the Ti−O−Ti form (labeled as O I), and the second one to the O species close to the oxygen vacancy (labeled as O II), and the one to the Ti−OH (labeled as O III), and the last one to the chemically adsorbed oxygen-containing species (such as H2O, labeled as O IV) [52]. The increase of Pd loading caused a gradual decline of the O II content in the catalysts. The O II content was 13.2%, 11.3%, 10.1%, 6.3%, 4.0%, and 1.5% for the TiH2, 0.2Pd/TiH2, 0.5Pd/TiH2, 1Pd/TiH2, 1.5Pd/TiH2 and 3Pd/TiH2, respectively, which may contribute to the adsorption of reactant under the reaction conditions as discussed later. Raman spectra of Pd/TiH2 catalysts were collected to examine their surface properties (Fig. S3). Raman lines were detected for 0.2Pd/TiH2 and 0.5Pd/TiH2 catalysts. The former displayed three broaden Raman lines at about 151cm−1, 420 cm−1, and 610 cm−1. The strong signal at 151 cm−1 should be related to the Eg mode (typically at ~ 144 cm−1) of anatase TiO2, and the ones at 420 and 610 cm−1 to the Eg (typically at ~ 445 cm−1) and A1g mode (typically at ~ 612cm−1) of rutile TiO2 [54,55]. The Raman line shifts for the anatase Eg mode and rutile Eg mode should be ascribed to the non-stoichiometry by oxygen deficiencies, disorder induced by minor phases, and others [54]. For 0.5Pd/TiH2 catalyst, only weak Eg and A1g modes related to rutile TiO2 were detected, whereas for the catalysts with Pd loading of > 1%, no signal was detected. Evidently, the 0.2Pd/TiH2 and 0.5Pd/TiH2 catalysts should have different surface TiOxHy structure from the catalysts with Pd loading of > 1%. Although no diffraction peaks assigned to TiO2 were observed in the XRD results, surface anatase or rutile phase with abundant defect sites might exist on the surface of 0.2Pd/TiH2 and 0.5Pd/TiH2 catalysts. Discussion and mechanism consideration The hydrogenation of FF could produce FOL, THFF, and THFA concurrently as the results shown in Fig. 1, and the product selectivity depended on Pd loading largely. Moreover, the structure and the surface property characterization as described above showed large difference for the examined Pd/TiH2 catalysts with different Pd loadings thus the relation of the product selectivity and surface properties of catalysts was discussed. Tuning the loading of Pd on the TiH2 support resulted in the changes of Pd sizes and electronic states of Pd, and the defect sites on the surface of TiH2. A higher loading content led to the formation of larger Pd nanoparticles and more Pd0 species on the surface. These may affect the adsorption of the reactant and product, and finally change the product selectivity. Therefore, the adsorption behavior of FF on TiH2 alone and Pd/TiH2 catalysts was examined by in situ DRIFT measurements. Fig. 8 gives the DRIFT spectra collected (the assignment of absorption bands observed is given in Table S7). For the TiH2 support alone, the physically adsorbed FF was removed rapidly and by flushing with He gas at 150 °C for 60 min, but FF adsorbed chemically still remained on the surface, for which the adsorption band at around 1400 cm−1, belonged to C=C bond, and those at 1660 and 1680 cm−1 indexed to stretching vibration of C=O group; It indicated that the FF could be adsorbed on the support TiH2 alone with its C=O bond, as the vibration intensity of C=O was much weaker than that of C=C, which is also in agreement to the reaction result that highly selective hydrogenation of in FF over the TiH2 support alone, yielding 100% FOL in selectivity (Table 1). For the Pd containing samples, stronger chemical adsorption of FF was observed. Both the vibration of C=O and C=C bonds could be detected on the Pd/TiH2 samples after He flushing for 60 min, and only the C=C stretching of furan ring vibration remained after 120 min. The vibration related to furan ring at 1150 and 1210 cm−1 and the adsorption was still stronger after flushing for 120 min for the sample of 3Pd/TiH2 catalyst, suggesting that the furan ring could be adsorbed on the surface of Pd as the adsorption intensity became stronger with an increase in the Pd loading. It is speculated that FF could adsorb via a strong interaction with its C=O bond on the defect/oxygen vacancy sites of the TiH2 support, and adsorb on the interfacial area of Pd particle and the defect/oxygen vacancy of TiH2 support as well. Such a strong interaction weakened the stretching of C=O bond and resulted in the weaker vibration of C=O compared with C=C or furan ring which was adsorbed on the surface of Pd particles. The contribution of Pd particles and Pd particle - TiH2 support interface was further examined by using the thiol-modified Pd/TiH2 catalysts, in which we assumed the surface of Pd particles was covered by the thiol molecules and became ineffective as active sites; in contrast, the interface remained active after the thiol modification because it was difficult to adsorb the thiol due to steric hindrance. The reaction results of the two thiol-modified catalysts, 0.5Pd/TiH2(SH) and 3Pd/TiH2(SH), are given in Table S8. The former showed a smaller rate of FF conversion but a higher FOL selectivity of 90% compared to 84% of thiol-untreated Pd/TiH2 catalyst at similar conversion levels (15–16%). Similar effects of the thiol modification on the FF conversion and FOL selectivity were observed with 3Pd/TiH2(SH) and 3Pd/TiH2 catalysts. The decrease in the rate of FF conversion should result from a decrease in the surface area of supported Pd particles by the thiol adsorption/covering. Those results indicate that the FOL selectivity can become larger when the contribution of the surface of Pd particles become smaller. The results support the above-mentioned aspect that the FF substrate adsorbed at the metal particle - support interface transforms into the FOL. A similar influence of thiol on the FF adsorption over supported Pd catalyst was reported by Medlin et al. They found that the presence of thiol remarkably reduced the adsorption of FF on the Pd terrace sites, but very less effect on the adsorption of FF on the Pd edge sites [36]. Furthermore, it was assumed that the oxygen vacancy (O II) as observed in Fig. 7 should contribute to the adsorption of FF as the selectivity of FOL had a relation with O II, the more oxygen vacancy possessed, the higher selectivity to FOL obtained (Fig. 9 ) although it is not a linear relation due to the effect of other factors. Based on the results discussed above, it was proposed that the boundary of Pd and the oxygen vacancy/defects of support served as the main adsorption sites for FF, where the C=O group of FF was strongly bonded on the oxygen vacancy/defect sites (on TiH2) close to the Pd particles. Such an adsorption configuration facilitate the activation of C=O bond, and finally lead to the high selectivity to FOL. As a result, the 0.2Pd/TiH2 and 0.5Pd/TiH2 showed the preferential hydrogenation of C=O bond but not the C=C bond of furan ring. For the Pd particle, it is preferential to adsorb furan ring of FF, and the higher Pd0/Pdδ+, the more adsorbing capacity and stronger adsorption. Stability The reusability of a selected 0.5Pd/TiH2 catalyst was examined and the results are shown in Table S9. Both the reaction rate and the selectivity to FOL declined in the second recycling run, indicating that the deactivation occurred, which should be induced by the structure change of the catalyst during the recycling. Therefore, the used 0.5Pd/TiH2 catalyst was characterized and compared with the fresh one. It was found that the aggregation of Pd particle occurred during recycling reaction as the average Pd particle size of used catalyst increased to 5.4 nm, as compared to 3.5 nm of the fresh catalyst as estimated by TEM (Fig. S4). In addition, the electronic state of Pd on the used catalyst changed in the recycling reaction, Pd 3d5/2 presented an obvious shift to the high binding energy compared to that of the fresh one as shown in Fig. S5, which suggested that the partial oxidation of Pd took place after reaction. In addition to the changes of the Pd nanoparticles, the structure and surface composition of the TiH2 support were also modified during the recycling reaction. The diffraction peaks of TiH2 in the used 0.5Pd/TiH2 catalyst became weakened and broadened, which resulted from the change in crystallinity of TiH2 (Fig. S6). In addition, much more surface hydroxyl and chemically adsorbed oxygen species presented on the used 0.5Pd/TiH2 catalyst compared with the fresh one as observed from O 1 s XPS in Fig. S7. Conclusions Selective hydrogenation of furfural (C=O versus C=C) was studied with several Pd/TiH2 catalysts with different Pd loadings in this work. Among the catalysts studied, the 0.5Pd/TiH2 showed 73% selectivity to FOL at 100% conversion. Defects of TiH2 and suitable particle size and electronic state of Pd accounted for the unique adsorption behavior of furfural, and thus resulted in the high selectivity to FOL. Over the 0.5Pd/TiH2 catalyst, furfural was preferentially adsorbed with its C=O group on the defect of the interface of metal particle - support and this was favourable for C=O selective hydrogenation to yield FOL. However, for the 3Pd/TiH2, it had larger Pd particle and less defects on the surface, so the furfural was preferably adsorbed on the Pd particles with its furan ring compared to the adsorption of C=O on the defects of the interface, thus decreasing the selectivity of FOL. The present results provide helpful information for further understanding and controlling the product selectivity in the selective hydrogenation based on the interfacial defect sites and the adsorption configurations. coredata.dc:description: In this work, the selective hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol has been studied over Pd/TiH2 catalysts. The catalytic performances of several catalysts with different Pd loading (0.2–3% in weight) were discussed, among which a higher selectivity to furfuryl alcohol was obtained over 0.5Pd/TiH2 and it gave rise to a 73% furfural alcohol selectivity at complete conversion at 60 °C. The physicochemical properties of catalysts were well characterized by TEM, XRD, XPS, Raman, TPR and TPD, as well as in-situ DRIFT for the adsorption of the reactant. The size and the electronic state of Pd particles, and the surface defects of catalysts presented significant influence on the catalytic performance. The furfural is preferentially adsorbed with its C=O bond on the boundary of Pd particle and TiH2 support, leading to the high selectivity to furfuryl alcohol.
coredata.dc:title: Selective hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol over Pd/TiH2 catalyst
